But these aren't robots like your Roomba or "Bot Wars" little bots. These are 1- ton, 8-foot tall behemoths. In this future, boxing has been outlawed and now only robots can fight in the big ring. Charlie is down on his luck and scrapes together spare robot parts and works his robots in small-town carnivals and flea markets.Charlie has an 11-year-old son, Max (Dakota Goyo) whom he has never seen. Max's mother has died and his aunt wants custody. This is fine with Charlie who makes a deal with the rich uncle : Charlie will take the boy for the summer so aunt and uncle can vacation in Italy in peace. In return, Charlie receives a large chunk of change that he can use to pay off his seedy loan sharks.Charlie and Max take up residence with Bailey Tallot (Evangelene Lilly) who is the daughter of Charlie's old trainer. She runs a training ring for new bots. On a trip to the robot junk yard, Max finds an old sparring bot (Atom) that still has some life in it. It turns out the robot can "shadow box" and can learn Charlie's ex-fighting skills. Max wants to enter Atom into the fights and convinces Charlie to take him on the circuit and win some fights. And we're off"Real Steel" is a very formulaic, predictable, and immensely fun sports story. And like any good sports story, it's not just about the sport, but about the relationships surrounding it. In a season with films like "The Fighter," and "Warrior," "Real Steal" (with its PG-13 rating) is clearly aimed at younger audiences. Still as an adult, I still found the movie very entertaining with its fine performances and fast pace.Hugh Jackman plays the role of Charlie as an every-man, down on his luck and trying hard to make good. But he is impetuous. Max is played by Dakota Goyo and is intelligent and adorable. He walks the line between smart-alecky brat and wise-beyond-his-years. And he comes out very warm and endearing. Evangeline Lilly is little more than the dispenser of exposition and eye-candy. Which she does quite well.If you've seen any of the movies I've mentioned or "Rocky" you'll recognize the formula. But it is played out with exceptional special effects and warm characters. You'll be rooting for the underdog and booing the bad guys and smiling all the way through the final scene. For good acting, great special effects, a story we all have seen before and can't seem to get enough of, I recommend you "See it in theaters."

title: So much more than a sports movie or a movie about robots!
text: I must be honest, I'm not a fan of sports movies - especially boxing or wrestling. 'Real Steel' is essentially a combination of both these sports, but it has robots doing the boxing! Now, that's an entirely different matter! Add Hugh Jackman and I'm interested...In the not too distant future robot fighting - or boxing - will probably be a reality. Hugh Jackman stars as Charlie Kenton - a loser, to put it mildly, who lives for robots. His life takes a turn for the worst - for him - when his girlfriend from whom he is separated dies, and he has to take custody of their 11-year old son, Max. Dakota Goyo, by the way, is excellent as Max.Charlie is an arrogant and over-confident guy who doesn't have time for kids, and he doesn't make a secret of it either. The only person who can tame him, is his good friend Bailey (Evangeline Lilly). I enjoyed the chemistry between them!Despite the film revolving around robots, this is a movie about human emotions. It is touching and endearing and hits the right spot on every level. I loved the way Max stole Charlie's heart, and the way it affected their lives. This is so much more than just a robot movie, or sports movie for that matter.The vibrant soundtrack makes for a lively film. 'Real Steel' is an excellent production. It has a beautiful ending for an all-round satisfying film. I love it!

title: Awesome!!!
text: Great movie!!! Everytime I research it I'm amazed. Gets me pumped at the end everytime. Every movie with someone from the TV show Lost at least gets 1 star from me too!!

title: Action and emotion go hand in hand! A very heart warming and feel good movie for sure!
text: Really great movie for all ages! My daughter, 3 years old, myself and my mother, 60, all enjoyed the movie very much. Please don't judge the movie based on the negative reviews. Give it a try and you will really love it! What more do we need? It was perfect the way it was!

title: A must watch
text: Real steel is by far one of the most well produced movies i've ever critiqued. Charlie, our main character, has a son, Max, that he doesn't desire to care for. He makes a deal with Maxs aunt to give her and her husband custody. Max has to spend his summer with his father he strongly dislikes, meanwhile his aunt comes back from her trip. Then it is agreed that custody is to be given to her after she returns. Neither does Max or Charlie agree with the idea of spending summer together. At first they are like same side magnets, repelling one another. With the similarities they share in boxing robots their friendship grows more and more everyday. It is shown extraordinarily well how their relationship builds and leads into an even better ending. Not to mention the lighting and angels never failed to satisfy the eye, and the special effects went above and beyond, making them look more realistic than any movie I've watched. It had a good even amount of action, heartfelt, and amusing scenes. Making this film a great family movie. Definitely recommend.

title: The perfect Father-Son movie.
text: ...I just got back from seeing this one.You take a kids love of giant robots, combine it with a teen-to-adult male's love of Mixed-Martial Arts or Boxing, you add in a loser-dad who finds himself in the discovery of the person that is his son and PRESTO: I am pretty sure this may be the perfect father-son bonding movie for this current generation.Hugh Jackman gives a pretty solid performance, and the kid manages to stay JUST this side of annoying, and remains likable and tolerable throughout. Heck, I think he's the perfect avatar for a 10 year old kid to experience this movie through. What kid WOULDN'T love finding their own fighting robot in the mud, fixing it up and putting it out there to dominate?Really likable rock'em'sock'em riff on ROCKY.I do have to say that the scene where Jackman's character gets beat up IS a bit on the intense side. Some younger viewers may be upset by it.However, the rest of the movie is pure Father-Son bliss!

title: Metal to the ... Metal
text: It's the old underdog story. Mixed in with some family fun and road trip action. Hugh Jackman obviously had fun doing that, though you do wonder sometimes where his motivations lie (especially when he looks burned out). Even more out of place -> Evangeline Lilly. I love that woman, but could the role be played by anyone else? Actually it could have been played by literally anyone.But this shouldn't really break the movie for you. What does count are the action scenes. And they really put their back into them. The movie is highly entertaining (while not original and highly predictable) and more than just decent. The nice story touch (the robot) is that you might see more there than there actually is ...

title: Worst movie I've seen in years!
text: I am only giving this movie 3 stars because of the fighting robots. This movie was a very bad ripoff from I, robot and Rocky. Only very very very bad. The acting was bad, the characters unbelievable, the script sucked, the story was the worst I have seen in years. Sure, fighting robots are cool, and even with no story at all I would have rewarded more stars. But this story was so bad, that I got irritated the whole movie. I haven't said this many times the word f#ck in two hours ever! I was actually hoping for the robot to shout out: ADRIAAAAAAAAN!So, no laughs, no thrills, no fun. Only fighting robots...And that kid, really, don't quit school! You can't act! Hugh, shame on you.

title: Stupid concept that works surprisingly well
text: When I first read about this movie whilst it was in production my immediate thoughts were of ridicule and schmaltz.I take it all back. This movie succeeds because the two main actors overlay their emotions and personalities onto the main robot character Atom. You actually forget that it(he) is a machine.Dakoto Goyo already has an impressive amount of work under his belt for a 12 year old. He definitely has the potential to be a big star.It's like Rocky for robots. If at the end of this movie you are not cheering for this piece of machinery then you have no soul.Looking forward to the sequel.

title: Full of clichés and visually amazing, "Real Steel" manages the feat of, in the midst of brutal fights, showing innocence by Max's vision
text: Directed by Shawn Levy, the feature introduces us to Charlie (Hugh Jackman), a former boxer in a world where no one cares about fights between humans anymore. His career controlling fighting robots, the country's favorite sport, is going from bad to worse. After the death of his ex-girlfriend, he is forced to spend a few months with his son, Max (Dakota Goyo). Accidentally, the two discover an old robot, Atom, in a scrapyard. The discredited machinery could be Charlie's key to the top and, in the process, help him connect with the boy.Initially, John Gatins' script establishes the world of 2020 well, where the story takes place, something strengthened by the art direction. Small technological details, all based on our current technology, and behind-the-scenes discussions of the sport (whether in the underground or in the main championship) help to give some credibility to what we see on screen. The question is precisely in the main plot. To be fair, the film had to give credit to Sylvester Stallone, given how big the influence of the "Rocky" series is during the projection. Most apparent are the training sequence, the way the fights (especially the final one) play out, and of course the villains.The antagonists are the couple Tak Mashido and Farra Lemkova, played by Karl Yune and Olga Fonda respectively. The impression given to the public is that Gatins simply took the script for "Rocky IV" and copied and pasted the lines of Ivan Drago and his wife. The one-dimensionality of the characters makes it impossible not to notice these similarities, something that underscores the dislike we feel for them, in a bizarre case of transference. Even the robot controlled by Mashido, Zeus, has a look that refers directly to Megatron from the original "Transformers" design, completing the "twenty-something" atmosphere that takes over the projection. Let's look at Atom's look. Simple and slender, its design is very functional. However, what ends up drawing more attention is a "smile" on the robot's face. This is one of the signs of one of the most preposterous plots I've ever seen, in which an attempt is made to sell the idea that Atom has consciousness. Such an idea comes out of nowhere and is developed in a subtle way like a sledgehammer, through a scene where Atom stands in front of a mirror, and goes absolutely nowhere.The picture of the world in 2020 doesn't look much different than it does today, with the exception of screens, whether cell phones or monitors with a thin, translucent display. No flying cars, bizarre houses or fancy machines. Except that in this world, there are robots that replace humans in sports fights, like boxing. The film touches very little on the "where, how and why" society exchanged real fighters for robots. He mentions that the sport became very violent, and that the robots did not cause sequelae in the competitors and that they excited people much more. It implies that at a certain point, all fighters retired and robot disputes gained official status in society, while they were also successful in the underworld, with illegal robot fight clubs, where there are no rules for combat and robots are dismantled. Until they become scrap.The interesting thing is that these details of the film's universe are placed on screen in a very natural way. There is no reason to feel strange about the fact that robots are only used for fighting, and that with all this robotic technology the film does not explore other aspects of this idea. I don't think it would fit, since robots don't have artificial intelligence, they are actually controlled by humans, like those remote-control cars that many had in childhood. They are machines. They don't have that reflection of conscience of films like "I, Robot" just to cite one example. And that's a positive point for the film, as films with robots almost always become films about artificial intelligence. Not here. By the way, it makes much more sense for technology to evolve to a point where we can control robots with remote controls similar to the joysticks we have in video games than to create a conscious robot that moves by itself right away.However, the film is not really about fighting robots, but about the relationship between a father and a son that he never had contact with. The robots are there as a visual effect, keeping the audience interested in continuing to watch. Especially because the theme "father who never had contact with his son" is one of the old Hollywood clichés. The duo's relationship is developed quite naturally by the script, explaining Max's resentment for his father, who is not very interested in his presence. Having lost his mother recently, he finds himself torn between his aunt's family or the arms of Charlie Kenton. Shawn Levy, well involved with good effect, establishes a parental degree of discovery, demanding complicity, which emphasizes interests: the father sees in the boy the possibility of making money, perceives the boy's talent in controlling the machines, but does not abandon his pessimism about what Max, a stranger to him, has to offer. In this way he seeks facilitations throughout the narrative. Max experiences the novelty, being the target of attention and living with someone who, in addition to being a father, has become an idol, despite the repressed torture.Also functioning as a motivational exercise - the uttered "you can" should excite - the film will stir up emotion in the audience, not only for the innocent proposal, but for the energy of its narration. Very moving, the work uses the best of motion capture to give the robots veracity. Sound mixing is another significant attribute. In the combat scenes, we hear the bodywork crumple along with the movements of the hardware turning over. In this current dispute in the best Rocky Balboa style, the rescue of a dream comes true with Charlie Kenton getting back to doing what he always liked: fighting. The glorification takes place in this return to the rings and in the possibility of creating a powerful fighter and a winner for life."Real Steel" brings many of these reflections without having to invent, just reproducing. For this, it has a script (by John Gatins), as said, full of clichés. Gatins ("Power Rangers") starts from the principle that, to reach the unknown, it is necessary to use what is already known. Shawn Levy (Night at the Museum trilogy), who has always demonstrated competence in managing banalities, directs in an energetic manner. Each scene seems to overflow, be it dramatic exaggeration or strength... Levy's incursion is clear: he wants to convey a message that is between the lines and, to achieve it, he needs excess. And the praise is due to the special effects. The robots are unbelievably real in the movie, "Transformers" quality, without Michael Bay's rollercoaster camera to loop and spin every five seconds. You can actually see the robots moving and fighting. Robots really look like robots, with all their imperfections in the way they react to certain things and even when they get hit a lot and the bodywork is all destroyed.In this scheme, the direction of photography by Mauro Fiore ("Avatar") and the production design by Tom Meyer ("Orphan") lavish creativity and grant fundamental details to the subjective understanding of the story. From the play of light and shadow that alternately hides the face of an embarrassed Charlie (Hugh Jackman) and illuminates little Max (Dakota Goyo); from the rusty and faded robot Ambush, passing through the samurai warrior Noisy Boy until unleashing on the masterpiece that is Atom (the robot that moves the plot) and its resemblance (which goes beyond aesthetics) with the Tin Man from the classic "The Wizard of Oz", everything seems to be built on effusive but solid foundations. If Danny Elfman ("Batman") can demonstrate a certain delivery to an autopilot, even so his composition has a very well balanced and organic mix that ends up triggering a kind of heavy-rap-metal. Unfortunately, on the other hand, his emotional interference seems to want to squeeze the audience at dramatic points in order to extract the tears that had the potential to be more natural.In addition to so much, "Real Steel" manages the feat of, in the midst of brutal fights, showing innocence. This, of course, thanks especially to Levy's choice for diluting the story by Max's vision. The boy, who shows fundamental feelings for the dissolution of the script (mainly admiration and curiosity), has as much charisma as his scene partner. Jackman doesn't make much of an effort to be a brute he loves, a Wolverine without Adamantium, and in that way, for his trajectory to matter to the audience. At the end of the day, no one who is interested in the poster for this film will pay the ticket to see good acting or an innovative story. If the spirit is to offer the same as always, but with good visual effects and plenty of beatings, at least that is met. Even if it is through a proposal of reality as unreal as it is improbable.Shawn Levy film (produced by Steven Spielberg) is a futuristic recap of "Rocky: A Fighter" (by John G. Avildsen, 1976) interspersed with "The Fighter (by Darren Aronofsky, 2008)" and "The Fighter" (by David O. Russell, 2010)". Probably not with the weight of these three, but it is a bold and valid enough blockbuster to continue going far beyond the box office (or subsequent profit) and the role of entertainment. A coherent film in its main insinuation, that, in the future (perhaps not too distant - but no longer in 2020), as we humanize robots, we will reach the power of gene creation.

title: I saw the poster from afar and for a long time I thought it was the movie Ryan Gosling was playing :)
text: I didn't want to watch this movie, it didn't make me curious. Also, I saw the poster from afar and for a long time I thought it was the movie Ryan Gosling was playing :) Frankly, the movie was like a family movie, it was fun.

title: More Than Just Rocky With Robots
text: This movie is a lot more than just "Rocky" with robots, though it does borrow heavily from the Rocky franchise, and it does have the heart of the first Rocky movie especially, it also has shades of the other Stallone movie "Over The Top" thrown in too. It is great family entertainment that both me and my son loved. Plot In A Paragraph: In the near future, where Robot Boxing is the worlds most popular sport. Former boxer Charlie (Hugh Hackman) struggles to make a living with patched-up robots in dodgy venues. When he unexpectedly has to look after his 11-year-old son Max (Dakato Goyo) for the summer, they go on a road trip, things look up for him as they bond over a robot Max found in the junk yard. Hugh Jackman is a handsome man in great shape, has charisma in spades and also happens to be one hell of a good actor. Dakato Goyo is not as annoying as most child actors in this type of role. Evangeline Lilly is great as Bailey, Charlie's landlord/friend/occasional love interest. All the cast do well in their roles Kevin Durand is perfectly annoying (he does so well, I'm disappointed I never got to see him get his comeuppance) James Rebhorn is as reliable as always and Anthony Mackie is fun in a supporting role too. Though the movie does follow the cliché of the stubborn child, teaching his immature father a life lesson it is very entertaining. A great father and son movie.

title: You Will Be Cheering At The End
text: In the vain of "Over The Top" (Sylvester Stallone, 1987), "Rocky" and even "Transformers" comes a movie that will have you standing and cheering. Yes the story has been told before and yes we are confronted with some cliché moments, nevertheless Real Steel is a winner. It is a hard hitting (literally), feel good movie. The fight scenes are very well choreographed ,thanks to the influence of Sugar Ray Leonard, and the acting was just as good. Robots beating each other senseless, a great story, good actors and some good humor everything a movie needs to be entertaining and that it was. As Roger says: TWO THUMBS UP...WAY UP!!!

title: Rocky Style Underdog Movie
text: I went and saw this at an early screening for a charity event. I got to meet Hugh Jackman and see the movie in Imax... Hugh is an amazing person, so down to earth and nice! He said it was an underdog story and was like Rocky, he was right. It really is like a cross between Rocky and Transformers. It's your typical Disney underdog story, but the special effects were nice and the kid (also played young Thor in Thor) was pretty funny. I really enjoyed it, even though it was predicable, but no one says that just because a movie is predictable doesn't mean it can't be good. It has some cursing, but nothing you wouldn't hear on network TV. It's a good family movie and I have already told all of my friends to check it out.

title: Robots fighting, humans reconciling.
text: While it takes a little while to get drawn into a world where something like watching robots box is taken as a legitimate sport instead of the pastime of little boys everywhere, Real Steal is a pretty entertaining flick. The story is a combination of two familiar types that have seen countless variations, the underdog athlete and the reuniting and bonding of an estranged father and son. Mixing the formulas together over the backdrop of a near-future where robot fighting has replaced human boxing as the violent sport of spectacle results in a movie that's often sappy and tugs at your heart-strings with obvious intent. Still, it's also occasionally thrilling. I'd honestly be surprised if the majority of viewers didn't have a smile on their face and a positive mood by the end of the movie, as it does manage to strike some genuine notes, especially near the end. Hugh Jackman plays such a convincingly selfish man that it actually means something when his character has his inevitable change of heart. Dakota Goyo does a decent job as Jackman's young son, though the dancing and over-the-top cuteness of the character did seem a little much at times. Evangeline Lilly has a rather small part that will nevertheless appeal to those who are following her post-Lost career. Nothing about Real Steel is outstanding (aside from what I feel is a very good performance by Jackman), but I liked it. The robot fight scenes are well-done for the most part and the acting is good, but what makes this movie worth watching is that despite how many similar movies I've seen, this kind of story still brings an emotional connection.

title: Adults stay away......Only for very young kids
text: I was half way through this but i had to turn this movie off when the boy starts dancing with the robot...... That says it all doesn't it really, i should of known better when i saw the name spielberg (produced it) as all his stuff is the same sappy formula over and over, but i wanted to give it a chance...... Afterall its fighting robots, It should be good right??? Well no its not the characters are stupid, especially the little boy... he speaks Japanese he programmes robots he dances with aforementioned robots and he can negotiates fight prices .......... Like cumon!!!!!!!!!Even just small annoyances like are we really meant to off taken such a technological jump in such a short period of time..... Everything about this film is predictable and terrible, please don't buy it, Hollywood and especially Spielberg need to be thought a lesson

title: Nice Movie for male/female
text: If you are looking for a movie which any gender will enjoy. Real Steel will be an excellent choice.Very light and interesting story.

title: Jab Jab Jab!
text: Oh boy! Didn't expect this out of a I-got-nothing-to-do-so-let's-watch-a-movie movie. Sweet memories of Rocky kicking his foes revived. Pepped up and fun, not a boring moment throughout, the movie actually had me throwing imaginary punches in the air! Hugh was his usual reckless charismatic self with the new kid giving some high performance moves and fantastic dialogue delivery. Dakota Goyo sure has some talent. What would I not give to see the "robot dance" by an actual robot! Plus with the audience in the theater cheering every robot punch given and jeering every blow taken, I actually felt I was ring side. Where else would you get to watch an amazing late night boxing match? Totally worth the time. This movie has a lot of spark, spirit and energy to it. Finally, well done Shawn Levy!

title: very good
text: I think the movie was good the visuals of the robots were very well done for the time period. I think the plot of the film was very engaging and different to usual films. The characters were very well thought out and allows you to engage with them. Overall a good movie. I think the camera angles in this film were very well done and they clearly represent different moods and convey the correct theme for the film. The best camera angles and shots i saw where the ones when the robots are fighting as the4y use a range of different camera shots which allows you to see the scene through different perspectives which i think enhanced this movie so much/

title: Just Fabulous - blew me away!
text: The start had me a little worried, but once we got to the REAL characters of the movie, the kid and the sparring bot, things got much more interesting! By the end I was fighting with the robot and loving every second, corny and clichéd or not - just a wonderful escape, perfect for the big screen!Danny Elfman did a superb job with the score - made you feel every emotion with great intensity. Hugh Jackman needs no comment, but the boy and his love interest were really well matched and did great jobs too! The integration of CGI and real imagery was superb and really never looked unrealistic, surprisingly!I loved it - just go see it!

title: Too long by 36 minutes
text: It's weird how you almost instantly love the nerd kid. But it's sort of hard to dislike Hugh Jackman. Though his character's written as an utter asshole. Dakota Goyo was breathtaking. Fantastic discovery! He'll remain an actor to watch if he hones his talent. Anyway, the script was too slow-paces. The film failed to draw me in within the first hour. Emotionless remote-controlled robots are just not very appealing. Then again, if you give a robot a personality and emotions, sending him to a fight like a dog or bull or cock is just inhuman and cruel. The film picks up visibly in the second half. The kid takes the lead, educating his father. That is quite nice to watch. But there are still some spots where the pace is lagging. Then again, the last fight was intense and refreshingly ambivalent. I found it a bit disappointing that they left the ending open concerning Max' and Charlie's fate. Be that as it may, this film would definitely have done better with only 90 minutes. Visually, it was more than okay. I watched it in crap quality but I really never stopped to think about how the robots were all just computer-generated. They looked real enough. Good job by the CGI-department here! The soundtrack was well-chosen, too. Normally I'm not one for rap music but it fitted. And Danny Elfman wrote a moving score for the parts in between. So, maybe not the most thrilling film I've ever seen (I was immensely bored a lot of the time because the story just didn't move on) it's an okay way to spend the evening. It did have it's moments.

title: Amazing Movie!
text: This is the most underrated movie of all time. This movie is an awesome movie and deserves more credit

title: Cool and original!
text: Thrilling and heartwarming sci-fi sports drama that packs an emotional punch.First and foremost, Hugh Jackman's performance as Charlie Kenton is a knockout. He brings a mix of charisma, vulnerability, and determination to the character, making him a flawed but endearing protagonist. Jackman's portrayal carries the emotional weight of the film and adds depth to the father-son dynamic at the heart of the story.The film's premise of robot boxing is a unique and exciting concept that blends futuristic technology with the adrenaline of a sports film. The robot battles are visually stunning and action-packed, delivering a spectacle that keeps you at the edge of your seat.Dakota Goyo's portrayal of Max, Charlie's estranged son, is impressive. He captures the innocence and resilience of the young boy, creating a heartfelt and believable connection with Jackman's character.The film's themes of redemption, family bonds, and second chances are beautifully woven into the narrative. Real Steel delivers an emotionally resonant story that tugs at the heartstrings and leaves you rooting for the underdog.The special effects and CGI work in the film are top-notch, bringing the robot fighters to life with incredible detail and realism. The attention to detail in the design of the robots adds authenticity to the futuristic world of robot boxing.The film's soundtrack, featuring a mix of energetic and emotional tunes, complements the action and adds an extra layer of excitement to the boxing sequences.In conclusion, Real Steel is a knockout of a film that balances heart-pounding action with heartfelt storytelling. With Hugh Jackman's powerful performance, the thrilling robot battles, and the touching father-son relationship, it's a movie that packs an emotional wallop.If you're looking for a film that combines sports drama, sci-fi elements, and heartfelt emotion, Real Steel is a must-watch. It's a crowd-pleasing and uplifting cinematic experience that will leave you cheering for the triumph of the human spirit and the power of family.

title: Rock'em Steel'em
text: I think this may be the perfect example of a background movie. A film that is, at it's core, supremely generic but has some great visual flourishes to capture your attention for brief intervals. Real Steel is a father/son movie with a boxing facade put over it and while it's actually enjoyable enough in it's own right it's pretty forgettable when you take away the main attraction. The big selling point here is the fighting robots. I mean, boxing robots? Yes please! The fact that it actually looks surprisingly decent is a huge boost as well but it's just not enough to distract from how vanilla the rest of this thing is.Until the ending. I do think there is something about this ending that is really great. It goes beyond your typical sports film and even the normal father/son fair because it doesn't so much focus on the relationship as much as the rekindling of lost passion and I give this points from breaking that mold just a bit.Overall, pretty generic movie but with FIGHTING ROBOTS! It's decently fun, just don't expect any next level filmmaking here and you'll be in for a potentially fun ride. Like I said, great as background noise to pop in, ignore the nonsense and just focus in on the awesome robo-boxing matches.

title: Great Movie Until The End
text: From beginning to mostly end this movie has a subtle way of getting to the punch and then it delivers time and time again with the fight scenes. Real Steel delivers in the same way/formula as any Rocky movie, any underdog movie, and it's exciting to watch. It leaves you smiling as you root for the father and son underdogs. But then the ending comes and the word of the day becomes C for Cheese. Real Steel does not deliver the goods with the ending. It becomes too forced/contrived and cheesy as heck. This movie was about a 9 for me until the ending. However, overall, it's a pretty good movie and worth the watch. Also, you can never go wrong watching the beautiful and stunning Evangeline Lilly either.

title: At least a 7.9!
text: This is a great movie! It should be at least a 7.9 here on IMDB! 😊 It's a great story of a father and his son.

title: Real Steel - A Real Treat
text: I watched this movie alone and I liked it very much. Then after years, I watched it again with my elder sister and her 3 kids. All of them liked it. So this film has something to attract everyone. The VFX were too good that we get a feeling that the robot action sequences were real. Hugh Jackman and Evengeline Lilly were given their top class performance in this flick. The movie is so engaging that for one instance when Lilly's character shout "Come on, ATOM" watching ATOM's fight with the mighty ZEUS, we as spectators could feel the adrenaline rush and gets goosebumps. I recommend this movie to all viewers, as this movie has the elements to satisfy all age-groups.

title: Could be a guilty pleasure
text: Rocky with robots would have been the pitch for this robot enthusiastic movie, and that is certainly what it is. The film is set in 2020 where boxing has been replaced with robots beating hell out of each which are controlled by humans. Hugh Jackman plays Charlie, who is a former boxer now attempting to find a way to making money in this new robotic sport. Unfortunately for Charlie though he is constantly failing in his goal and his robots are being smashed up by either other robots or rodeo bulls. His other trouble is his arrogance in that he keeps gambling his make believe money on fights he believes he will win but ends up losing, meaning he owes lots of people lots of money. After hearing the news of a former partner's death he learns that he has a son who he must now care for. A son that he instantly sells to a former relative for money towards his next robot, the only catch is he has to look after the boy for the summer as his new parents are off across the World. Charlie continues on with his life despite the interference of his new son, and once again continues to lose his robots, up until his son becomes his lucky charm and finds a robot buried in a scrap yard. This robot was generally used as a training machine but the now Father and Son team begin to train the robot and slowly begin to rise through the ranks to the major leagues of the robot boxing world.As you can tell this is definitely Rocky with robots. The underdog will rise through the ranks, he will get his title shot, he will be the people's champ, and he will connect a bond between other people in his life. This could simply be what Real Steel is and from watching the trailer alone it is showing us a generic story made completely original. This really put me off in the trailer and I was never fussed about watching it but to be honest I am so glad I did.This is definitely one of those films that will be many people's guilty pleasure. It is such fun to watch and really has an emotional core to it that I didn't expect it to have. Everyone loves watching robots beating hell out of each other but what is good about this is it stops that before it has the opportunity of becoming boring and propels us to the other story which is the building bond between Father and son. These are not the only two story threads however as there are others that connect Charlie with a love interest, former relatives, and former enemies without even mentioning their main nemesis in the robot boxing world. For a story that seemed so unoriginal in the trailer it really does have many story threads to keep you gripped. That certainly was a shock for the system.Hugh Jackman is known mainly for playing Wolverine but here he plays something completely different. Granted he won't win any major awards for this performance but at times I forgot who he was and believed he was Charlie. Other than a couple moments of over acting and a few cheesy lines, he pretty much nails this performance. Dakota Goyo is also a strong performer as his son Max, my only quibble about him being that he seems awfully knowledgeable and confident for an eleven year old kid. Everyone else in the film does the job they set out to do.The script is also surprisingly good. It does have many cheesy moments especially in the final act but the dialogue throughout is realistic and there is some obvious and subtle humour put in there. At times there are some great lines, delivered really well, that are so subtle you need to really listen to hear them, and they are great. The direction is also really good, especially the fight scenes which will have you on edge. The CGI for the robots also looks fantastic, and despite the fast cutting to avoid continuity, look very realistic for the world they are in. The robots also look like they are standing alongside humans and not actual effects.The film is definitely a pleasant surprise. It does have a few cheesy moments and the second act does have a slight lull but there is enough in there for everyone to enjoy. It is a film I have seen twice now and I enjoyed it as much the second time as I did the first. This isn't just Rocky with robots, it certainly has something more.3 / 5For more reviews: www.tolli-movieworld.blogspot.com

title: Typical american movie: a despicable, immoral jackass become hero
text:
I'm getting tired of this stereotypical american movie. Seems to be all prominent movie writers has no sense of morality whatsoever with their self-interpreted/broken christian theology or none at all.
In almost every american movies, the main character is always started as an immoral person; cheater, liar, conman, bully etc. because they think it's relatable to audience (read: americans -- thus everyone else on earth seemed to have a much higher moral standing).
Then after some cheesy redemption, the main character become a hero or a chosen-one, regardless of what he/she has done, no retaliation (as long as you believe blah-blah-blah, all your sins will be forgiven and enter the holy kingdom).
In non-american movies (particularly traditional asian) the hero is always pure and virtuous from the beginning, however wrecked the world the protagonist never bargain with his/her integrity. that's also the very reason why he/she become the chosen-one.

title: Great Movie, Underrated
text: I went into the movie expecting nothing, and it was well worth the money I spent!Like so many great movies (Battle for Los Angeles comes to mind) this movie is underrated by many critics with no imagination , this movie was great, the story revolves around a dead beat dad who through the bot fights, learns to fight for what is important, his son. Although I am not a smarmy critic, everyone (self included) in the theater was cheering during the entire movie. For a movie to cause that must mean they are doing something right. Now while some think the formula is overplayed, it is well performed, and unique enough to really get you going. This movie is a real sleeper hit. While it may not appeal to all, it definitely is a movie with some heart to it. Which I in all my non- elitist glory recommend to us normal folk who just downright enjoy something entertaining and heart warming.

title: Could've been better
text: To me this film had such a good, realistic story line however without being too harsh this was ruined by the character of the kid, it spun realism completely out of proportion with no 11 year old being that confident or supposed genius with robots, it just doesn't seem right, it screams Anakin from the Phantom menace.Other than that I really felt the film to have a great mix of emotions, even if sometimes they were a bit larger than life, the story had a good , sometimes predictable, development.And the creation of the robots was brilliant, they really did blend seamlessly with the film, it wasn't even a noticeable difference between what was real and fake.Overall quite a good film, maybe a bit too unrealistic in places, however for a child actor I suppose he didn't do too bad. I would recommend it.

title: An emotional roller-coaster
text: This movie is a perfect blend of comedy, action and values. I was blown away by Dakota Goyo's performance and the chemistry he had with Hugh Jackman (and Atom). The plot keeps you excited about what happens next and there was a perfect balance of action and drama. The fight scenes were very realistic and we are dragged along together with Atom, Charlie & Max throughout the emotional journey that they are undertaking. Hats off to the writers who created a main character (Charlie Kenton) who is an asshole but you cannot stop rooting for him. From the first minute of the film, you start to feel involve with him and this doesn't stop until the last minute. Overall, a very good film and I hope Hollywood won't spoil it by having a sequel.

title: Great Movie. A Fun movie for a change.
text: Rockem-Sockem Robots meets Rocky with a get the family back together theme. I got to see the movie in an advance screening tonight. The whole theater was at times applauding and whooping it up. This is not high-brow, intellectual docudrama or supposed to be real. This movie is fun. It is meant to be fun. The kid steals the show. The meaning I brought home from this movie is heart. If you have heart, there is nothing in this world that can stop you from your dream. Just like "The Little Engine That Could." I really don't want to give away any spoilers here, just advice. If you want to feel good about life, and fighting the good fight, then go see this movie. You will be glad you did. I am not a movie critic nor will I ever be one. But I know what makes good movie and this one has tons of heart.

title: Real Steel (2011) - Finally, A Robot Movie that Actually Makes Sense!
text: Hugh Jackman stars an ex-boxer, now training robot wrestlers, searching for redemption with the help of his long-forgotten son, and a mechanical piece of robotics. So, this movie is basically about a bunch of mechanic robots fighting each other, controlled with a video game controller. The movie, "Rock-em, Sock-em Robots" (just kidding!), I meant "Real Steel" has a perfect premise to this movie and it delivers more entertainment, more perfection, and more better action than the mighty crap of "Transformers 3". Director Shawn Levy finally improves his career after directing hit comedies like "Cheaper by the Dozen", "The Pink Panther", and "Night at the Museum". He really made an interesting movie that makes sense to everyone, and it's something that everyone could relate to. All the action scenes in this movie worked perfectly, and the special effects are extremely groundbreaking. The music is super inspiring, and the cinematography is so totally super. Hugh Jackman delivers one of the best performances in his career, and he steals the show in every scene he is in. I also really liked Evangeline Lilly in this movie as Jackman's ex who still believes in him. Dakota Goyo makes a total breakthrough performance as Jackman's long-lost son who suddenly is inspired to join the ring with his father. But out of all that, this is a movie that contains a warm spot, a real heart to the story is added. That's the type of robot movie that is perfect to watch, rather than the unexplainable "Transformers 3". "Real Steel" has a perfect script, a brilliant cast, amazing visual effects, awesome fight scenes, and the heart of the story works perfectly, which proves that this movie is one of the better movies of the year. "Real Steel", in my review, "a heartwarming feature, with groundbreaking visuals".

title: A feel good yarn.
text: I didn't think I'd like Real Steel. In fact when I popped it on, I was sure I'd be witching it off after 15 minutes. But in the end I was rooting for the little underdog robot fighter, despite there's not one original bone in the movie.What it boils down is, that Real Steel is a feel good movie. It knows everything in it has been done before in sports movies and father/son bonding stories. But at the same time the movie manages to do those all so familiar plot twists and turns pretty well and with ease many other movies, that aren't about robot boxing and sons looking to bond with their estranged fathers, simply aren't able to do.So, after doubtful start, I was, in the end, in a pretty good mood. Every plot element I had guessed before hand, but despite the ending that is riffing Rocky and pretty much every underdog sports movie, the movie had made a big smile on my face. It isn't a masterpiece, but it is a fun little movie, that aims to make you feel good, because in the end everyone learns a lesson and a sun peeks from behind the clouds.

title: Appalling, degenerating
text: The most awful thing I've ever seen. Absolutely atrocious. This kind of film should be banned. It's definitely not meant for adults and it will make your kids lose any intellect they have if they watch it to the end.I had such an extreme emotion about this film, that I had a tear coming out of my eye during watching. And the emotion was extremely negative.the score is 1/10This film reminds of "Idiocracy", but this time "idiots" are for real.I cannot recommend this film to anyone, even if you a person that can potentially enjoy it. Trust me - It will make you no good.Stan UK

title: Frankenstein
text: It seems that a successful Hollywood script is one that seems to do something new by recycling trusted parts of bankable film ideas. This one — to judge from the tickets sold — picked good enough bits. Father stuff; coming of age stuff; techno; Karate Kid; Iron Giant.But a viewer demographic must be a vexing thing to these factory filmmakers, because some viewers will see the cobbled together being and see parts that were missing, parts that would have made the being stronger. Such was the case with me because I saw this foremost as a boxing movie and I looked for the cinematic thrills that could have been there.After all, the boxing movie is one of the primary paths where we evolve our notion of the camera. Scorcese of course, but many others brought us novel ways to think about who we are in the choreography of how a closed bit of the world dances.And that wasn't here even though our combatants are computer generated and our greatest advances in camera choreography have been in cameras whose placement and movement are not restricted by physical bounds.Nope. None of that here. We may as well have just been watching muscle cars in a demolition derby.Boxing, some might say, is the only true sport. One man against another and the first one that cannot continue loses. Sport — at least this notion — is about losing; the dream is about winning. It is a strange thing, the notion of contest. It is between two men, but if it were truly pure, they would go off and conduct the contest in private, as many do with say the contest of chess.But this seems to have been designed more for spectators. Rules having to do with space. With gloves and rests designed to make it last long enough to be worth traveling to gather in large numbers. Commentary and statistics that one can carry from contest to contest. A personality industry so we believe we have some choice in who we prefer.These are exploited here, well enough I must admit. But there is no dance.Ted's Evaluation -- 1 of 3: You can find something better to do with this part of your life.

title: Nice action for the family viewers
text: The story is another fatherhood thing, a common theme for family oriented movies. And the story gets more in common with the more recent family movie where the father figure is told as a reluctant, if not in denial, at first as a daddy. The developed story goes on as the common fatherhood movies, where the father and the kid finds the one thing they like in common and build relationship and bond more on it, despite it being a long shot, and eventually wins out the long shot. What's good about this one is that, unlike most other fatherhood movies where it's only the father that gets to do the struggle while the kid only shouts from behind to lift his spirit up, this movie presents that actually the kid can do something too. Jackman, as always, played this one nicely. It's good to see Dakota Goyo can balance the aura of Hugh Jackman. Also it's nice too Evangeline Lily's earlier works here.

title: is that ROCKY balboa movie with robots?
text: ROCKY similar story only one big different robots and little things in story line. but its really enjoyable movie to watch really good CGI and good effects but i think its not a lot. yea its cool to watch fighting robots with really good effects but nope. if you like story you must watch ROCKY and not real steel but if you are watching for enjoy its really good movie to waste time. 10/4 - meCharlie Kenton (Hugh Jackman) used to be a prizefighter but lost his chance to win a title when heavy, towering robots took over the boxing ring. Now working as a small-time promoter, Charlie pieces together scrap metal into low-end fighters, barely earning enough to make it from one underground venue to the next. After hitting rock bottom, Charlie reluctantly teams with his estranged son, Max (Dakota Goyo), to build and train a championship robot for a last shot at redemption.and now rocky review.Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone), a small-time boxer from working- class Philadelphia, is arbitrarily chosen to take on the reigning world heavyweight champion, Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers), when the undefeated fighter's scheduled opponent is injured. While training with feisty former bantamweight contender Mickey Goldmill (Burgess Meredith), Rocky tentatively begins a relationship with Adrian (Talia Shire), the wallflower sister of his meat-packer pal Paulie (Burt Young).that's mini review of film but this two movies have similar ending.

title: A great way to spend a couple of hours with the family.
text: What a great movie. Family friendly (for the most part) with very good acting. Suspend your imagination and enjoy the Rocky of robot movies.From a short story by Richard Matheson and previously brought to the small screen in the original Twilight Zone, the movie is full of everything you would want to watch while downing a bucket of popcorn. Robots. Fights. A father trying to reconnect with his son. And a lot of action.Is it predictable? You bet.Can it keep your attention? Definitely.Does it have Academy Award winning anything? Heck no.Its just has the most important thing for a movie. It's fun.

title: Solid Movie, but not perfect
text: I really can't describe how much I love this movie, the CGI, the practical effects, all of it, I really thought the robots were real. I really love Hugh Jackman here, the acting from Evangeline Lilly is good too, the kid was great (Forgot his name tho), it's a pretty solid movie, has good jokes, but it's not perfect.

title: Real Entertainment!!
text: This movie is amazing! The CGI is excellent!! The casting of Hugh Jackman, Dakota Goyo and Evangeline Lily is just match made in heaven. Boxing fight never get any exciting than this. I normally don't like boxing because of all the bloody and sweat so I don't watch Rocky movies. But robot boxing is totally cool with all those metals busting around. Atom the junkyard robot is the CGI star in this show. Both Hugh Jackman and Dakota Goyo play their role very well. Plenty of emotions and sometimes annoying but they will grow on you. And the music score is really good!!! Those metal punches sounds real good. And the music really brings out the emotion out. Combined with the actors emotions showed, it is a total win. Real steel packs 2011 up!!! This is real entertainment!!!

title: The Vidiot Reviews...
text: Real SteelThe worst thing about robot boxers is their inability to grasp the concept of "taking a dive" without self-destructing. Fortunately, the pubescent manager of the steel-plated pugilist in this sci-fi movie has got too much integrity for bribes.Following his mother's death Max (Dakota Goyo) becomes the ward of his affluent aunt (Hope Davis).But with a vacation on the horizon, she must bribe his father, an ex-boxer (Hugh Jackman), to safeguard him until her return.Under his supervision, Max recuperates a robot, which he and his dad enter into bouts. On the eve of their title shot, however, Max is removed from the event after his dad's creditors come looking for their cut.In spite of its cheesy lines and flamboyant bouts, Real Steel has real heart underneath its steely exterior. And while watching boxing with your absentee father can be healing, beating him up would be more rewarding. (Green Light)vidiotreviews.blogspot.com

title: Formulaic schlock
text: I had the displeasure of watching this on a plane flight recently. The CG looked goofy. The bad guys were like villains out of the worst Karate Kid films. The most engaging character was made out of metal. There is no emotional wind-up, because the outcome of every scene is obvious as soon as it starts. The scenes which are supposed to be uplifting and emotional are so corny that I was laughing instead of crying. It's like a movie of Rock 'Em Sock 'Em Robots, with all of the depth and complexity of the original game.That said, it's probably a good way to keep (young) kids entertained for an afternoon.

title: Applause for Real Steel
text: A nice effort from sh-awn levy.. A worthy movie to watch in theatre.. The end was a good one since it shows something realistic.. While coming to characters Dakota Goyo outperformed Hugh Jackman..lol Real Steel comes from director Shawn Levy, whose entire niche is family friendly fare. As for story, this is a movie about family bonding more so than robotics, the sweet science, or training. It hinges on Hugh and Dakota so that's it's simply not a collection of brawls. The two get along fine, and though Max is written like the father figure many will take relief in his maturity. Real Steel has a plot that's aimed right at the kiddos with easy to distinguish good and bad figures. Of course the ice-cold Russian-Japanese duo behind the reigning champ Zeus don't have relatable family struggles to put them in a gray area.

title: Rock-em Sock-em Robots
text: I think that it is a pretty interesting take on the old Rock-em Sock-em Robots that I grew up with as a kid.Enjoyed it for what it is...a fun feel good movie. A dead-beat dad gets a clue, the bull doesn't get hurt, and there weren't bullets flying everywhere. Imagine that.The special effects were pretty good, in fact I would put them better than another fighting robot movie that used the cover of shaking camera's to hide detail and simulate real action.Also liked how this movie combined Transformers, Every Which Way but Loose, The Mighty Ducks, and professional wrestling all into one feature.

title: A Must-See!
text: The World we live in, gets complicated more and more each day. Civilization advances, thus Technology is influencing our lives more and more, as we go on. In These Times, as well as to the Times Ahead, it is so Good to know that some things still remain the same. Faith, Love, Hope, Effort, and Ultimately Success!Those Values are The Essence of Our Existence. As long as we Honor them throughout our Existence, nothing can hold us back!This Film is All About Them! Enjoy It!

title: Rocky's son - a robot
text: The story of this film is like a mash up of two Sylvester Stallone movies: Rocky (of course), the story of the indomitable boxer who, most of all, had so much willpower (and hard shell) that he just wouldn't stay down and Over the Top, where he is a tough truck driver playing at scanderberg while reconnecting with his son. The robots are fun, but inconsequential to the story itself.You see, in a world where boxing matches are done with robots, an old generation bot is tough and relies more on its handler's commands than on its programming. In the end the father and son team battle the robot of a rich Russian woman and her pet Japanese programmer. Yeah, they used a tiny bit of Rambo as well, apparently.The film was a nice feel good movie. The technical aspects were ludicrous, but again, not relevant, the actors played well and the story, as predictable as it can be, was nice nevertheless. A thumbs down for using women as walking clichés. A thumb up for using Kevin Durand, who is among my favorite bad ass actors. Bottom line: everything I expected and a little more, thanks to Hugh Jackman and Dakota Goyo, who carried the film.

title: What a Surprise!
text: I've had this movie for quite a long time now, but I thought it was going to be a cheesy film, so I never watched it. What a surprise! Although it feels like a very expensive kid's movie, I have to admit I had not enjoyed any aimed-for-the- adults movie so much for quite a long time. The movie and the outcome of every single match were very predictable (it's a kid's movie after all!) yet it somehow managed to get me all excited. Right now I'm thinking if I've seen a real action movie that came close in delivering this level of joy and excitementFace/Off maybe. The CGI used here is some of the best I've seen. You can't tell if the robots are real or computer-generated. The actors do a really great job in showing a wide range of emotions, although the ending failed to make me all emotional due to the childish nature of the movie. The fights were really exciting, even though the end result was clear from the start, and this has to be the movie's greatest accomplishment. I strongly recommend this movie to anyone who feels he/she can still communicate with the child within.

title: "Best movie eva." Dannen, 8yrs old
text: OK, I know you die-hard film reviewers take your job very seriously so no disrespect, but really, getting your panties in a bunch over this film, well, its just not worth it. I just finished watching this movie, with my attention-deficit prone kids, Grace, 9yrs & Dannen, 8yrs and their rating was that it was probably the best movie ever. Thats 10/10 in anybody's language. ....and really, thats the only rating that counts. Considering the target audience, the bonus was, mum & dad could watch it too and have fun with it. Its a kids/family movie, it doesn't bear any closer scrutiny than that. Those blatantly negative reviewers either, 1. Never had kids, or 2. Forgot what it was to be a kid, or 3. Take their movie reviewing career waaaay too seriously. I only signed up with (whatsitcalled?) oh, thats it, IMDb.com so I could comment on this movie as I normally am too high-brow for you lot ;), but, in the interests of promoting quality family-time, I can only suggest, watch this movie with your kids. You will smile along the way and as my boy said at the conclusion, "Yeah dad, prob best movie eva..."

title: An Alternate Universe or Rocky
text: This could be seen as an alternate universe Rocky movie. It pretty much follows the trajectory of that movie with a bit of a twist. What if weeks before Rocky was to get his big break the Rocky Balboa was to get his big break the box world shut down boxing as barberic and dangerous and starting using robots as fightsers instead? What would happen to fighters like Rocky who had nothing else?Again this follows the same basic trajectory but maybe a decade later and has the son of a out of work former boxer who has his son forced on him for the summer because his ex wife and her husband want to go away for the summer and the son find a robot in the trash and the two slowly find an bond they never hand while turning this unlikely robot into a champion.

title: Better Than Expected
text: "Real Steel" (2011) is a considerably above average example of what I call the "CGI laser light show" movie genre, much better than most (insert "Sucker Punch" here). Think "The Champ" (1931) with elements from "Transformers" (2004), "Rocky" (the 1976 original), and "Terminator 2: Judgment Day" (1991).At its core it is another redemption tale as aging boxer Charlie Kenton (Hugh Jackman) gets a chance to be a father to the now eleven year-old son he abandoned at birth (Max Kenton - nicely played by Dakota Goyo). Charlie is informed that his ex-wife has died and he leaps at the chance to cut a deal with his wealthy sister-in-law to give her custody of the boy. But through a series of somewhat contrived events the jaded Charlie ends up with Max for the first summer.The secret to this type of fairy tale lies in how well they connect with viewers; if the movie can get viewers to strongly identify with the character (in this case Max) as he gets a huge rush from suddenly becoming part of the robot-fighting world, the viewer will get hooked. Then the challenge is to keep them hooked for as long as possible. "Real Steel" hooks you and provides this vicarious rush well past the midway point, in large part because of the twist of having Max bond with the robot as a surrogate father, much in the spirit of "Terminator 2" but also nicely integrated with the ongoing dynamic of the old robot being Charlie's twin or at least the piece that completes him . But eventually the wheels fall off, or in this case get knocked off by a "Rocky" scripted overreach. The illusion bursts and most viewers crash back to reality because it takes too much mental energy to suspend disbelief when the team breaks into the glitzy celebrity world. From that point on it is just overwrought melodrama, with the inspirational "redemption on steroids" theme aggressively shoved down each viewer's throat.Of course this surfeit of cliché might have been palatable but for Kevin Durand's overplayed heavy. Like a series of cardiac arrests the heart of the movie first begins beating irregularly during his debt collection sequence, is then severely damaged by his lame homeboys routine, and finally succumbs from his sequence at the conclusion of the first round of the climatic fight. These would make great deleted scenes for the DVD release but should have been mercifully trimmed from the already too-long film.The one positive of the glitzy sequences was Olga Fonda's "Farra Lemkova" character, an amped up to super-hotness play on WWE's Stephanie McMahon. She provided the film's most interesting images, a kind of an embodiment of slick temptation. Can't say the same for Karl Yune's Asian robot designer who essentially was tasked with the Apollo Creed role. Part of Rocky's success lay in Creed's newly acknowledged respect for Rocky at the conclusion of the film, this allowed the ending to transcend its cliché elements because it nicely blunted the obvious good vs evil dynamic. Yune was not allowed to play his character this way and "Real Steel" loses considerable depth, dimension, and IQ points because of it.Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.

title: What's not to like about fighting robots
text: Rating-6/10Real Steel is an action movie containing not only boxing robots, Wolverine and good effects, but also a truly thought out plot that may not be too original in fairness but still a nice enough movie in any case. With high octane fights and acting not too bad to say this is made up with lots of CGI, The producers of this film really don't do a bad job in getting it all together and one of them executive producers is none other than Steven Spielberg. The film itself is a good length and although it made me feel slightly sleepy at times, it still conjures up good things. Hugh Jackman is OK as the main character Charlie and his son played by Dakota Goyo is actually well cast, as Goyo seems to fit well with the story and he could be a young actor to look out for in the future. Evangeline Lilly is charming as ever and although not at her full potential as an actor here, she still brings a certain air of calm headed coolness and seems a refreshingly different pace in the film.Shawn Levy directs this and his eye is not immediately on point it can seem and parts can be a little, say dodgy with too much action in certain parts but then none at all for a good length of time. I felt the heavy metal score placed down on this film was not one that drew me into the fighting, it only caused me to want the fight to end but I can see for some that they would find it more exhilarating than me. It is written well and the two guys who do the screenplay(Dan Gilroy and Jeremy Leven) don't hurt the movie but don't provide any assistance to the already seen type of plot.The effects are one thing that stand out in this movie and on reflection they are very nice and it's no wonder it got an Academy Award nomination for Best Visual Effects. It may seem or feel that the effects could over shadow the true feeling in the film but I felt any emotion the characters show is shown well enough through all the big budget stuff. It's not over dramatic storytelling(although the ending without spoiling is well, cheesy cheesy and more cheese), you'll notice if you see how the movie starts slow but really picks up a pace and although not rushing into it's ending, seems to want to finish without a bang.My review may seem as if I did not enjoy this, or maybe even like I liked this much more than I did but in truth I found it kind of OK and although not quite Good, still acceptable in the vast CGI action movie catalogue, that seems to get bigger every year. I gave it an OK-ish feeling review and that may seem harsh and I know for sure that some people will read this and completely disagree with what I have been saying but you have to like action to like this, not just Sci-Fi story telling, you have to like straight all out fighting. The film has true heart there is no doubt, one last thing I want to say about this is that you can feel for those involved and Hugh Jackman although maybe not at his absolute best, still draws you in. Give it a go even if you don't enjoy all out action because it may just surprise you how much you actually liked it, not easy to like but possible and it is wrong to say only a certain demographic would enjoy this.

title: A Knockout Fusion
text: In the exciting future shown in Real Steel, boxing has transformed into a sport dominated by enormous robots that are operated by humans. The movie centers on the unlikely champion that Charlie Kenton, a former boxer, and his son Max find in Atom, an antiquated robot. The picture gains complexity from Hugh Jackman's portrayal of Charlie, who must balance parenting, atonement, and the unshakable bond formed in the harsh world of robot boxing. With visually stunning robot combat and an intense bond between Charlie and Max, the movie finds a balance between heart-wrenching scenes and jaw-dropping action sequences. Real Steel is an incredible hit that has a profound effect on themes of resiliency, opportunities for redemption, and the eternal value of human connection.

title: Good crowd pleasing stuff, recommended
text: In the not so distant future, human boxing has been overtaken by a new sport. A sport where the contenders can be smashed, decapitated and executed at the crowds will.Robot boxing is big business with a huge following, neither phrase could ever be applied to Charlie Kenton (Hugh Jackman). Charlie is a struggling washed up ex-boxer, always believing he is just one win away from making good.Following one fight too many, he is sans robot, not a good space to be in, when fighting is your game. Fortunately Charlie has a long suffering back stop, on/off girlfriend Bailey (Evangeline Lilly), who in real life would be backstop for nobody.Charlie needs to score some serious cash soon. Fortunately he can sell his 11 year old son, by gifting his custody rights to a well meaning sister in-law. Motherless, poor old Max (Dakota Goya) has been living in miserable luxury but his Aunt wants to make it all official.Soon the pair are on the road, following a convenient hiatus as the rich folk go to Tuscany, Charlie is not happy, he just wanted the money, not a moppet in tow.Maybe Charlie has gone too many rounds, as his business sense leaves something to be desired. Max who rather fortunately, is a massive Robot boxing fan, has his head screwed on better than Charlie's robots.Alighting on a old Sparring bot "Adam", the pair start their journey from the bottom, Max with stars in his eyes and Charlie with his eye on the main chance and one last shot at glory.Charlie is an unlikeable character and Jackman literally pulls no punches in his ambivalence towards Max, involving him in scrapes and situations, no responsible parent ever should.The effects are seamless, CGI robots interact with the live actors and environments, the audience believing immediately they are real. Goya is no cute movie moppet, giving as good as he gets and clearly having the time of his young life. Jackman is solid and believable and as mentioned, does not take the easy acting route.Ultimately this is robots fighting in a ring, which is hard to dislike. However, if you imagine what you think this movie will be like, add about another half as much again, for the real emotion and drama the film manages to evoke.When watching the simulated Robot boxing sport, it's not so much a question of will this ever exist in reality, it's just a question of when.Finishing with a rousing and well staged ending, the Director is clearly confident enough to pause the action for a worthwhile and poignant slow motion sequence, leaving you with a smile on your face.Summary If you are expecting a standard formulaic father son bonding flick with added robots, this covers those bases, but adds depth and much more.Good crowd pleasing stuff, recommendedhttp://julesmoviereviews.blogspot.co.nz/

title: My Comment about Real Steel
text: Real Steel is a great movie. This is movie is directed by Steven Spielberg. It is almost the same with Transformers, but in Real Steel the robots are a kind of boxer robots those are controlled by humans.It is about a collaboration between a father and his son. The father teaches the robot many kinds of tricks in boxing. There are uppercut, and the others. The good side of this movie is that it doesn't imitate the other movies about robot, because most of all movies with the same theme feature similar robots with Transformers. The lack of this movie is that the storyline is almost the same with the other movies' , first the good people are lost,but at the end they always win.By:Alien

title: good film good story
text: i went to go see this film at the cinema recently i love hugh jackman and most of his films that he is in the story in this film is great hugh is a past it boxer who finds out he has to look after his son hugh now a robot boxing instructor takes his son in hand and shows him his life and his job . i loved this story as it showed u what hugh had to do to get on his sons good side and the robot fighting is great what more could you ask for in a film a good story and there is robots in it fell good movie a good watch for all the family. if u are a big kid at heart then u will love this.i loved the way this movie made me feel after i had left the movie theater thats when i know i just watched a good film.

title: What a good movie. Clank Clank
text: This movie has fighting, robots, and Hugh Jackman. What is their not to like about this movie. Just skip the parts that aren't fighting, and enjoy cgi robots fighting each other. Its like pacific rim but more realistic. 10/10 would watch again.

title: A Robo-Boxing Family Drama
text: 13 February 2012. Take Rocky (1976) and a plucky boy who appears to have more maturity or is more suited (as the script calls for) being the father of the typical movie father who abandoned his son, lost his custody of his son and who apparently never grew up (for most of the movie anyway).The son's character is a bit grating at times and takes the dominate role while his father almost appears to be witless and can't avoid being child (no wonder his wife divorced him). Unlike strong children, seemingly all girl leads such as in Where the Lilies Bloom (1971), Winter's Bones (2010), Fly Away Home (1996), The Secret of Roan Inish (1995), Little Miss Sunshine (2006) or for a strong boy role Hugo (2011) or Incredibly Loud and Extremely Close (2011), Dakota Goyo comes off cocky and full of himself from the movie script. One strong child male protagonist with a more balanced adult-child relationship can be found in The Cidar House Rules (1999). While such a character might delight to young kids, such enterprising in your face kids seem more like a daunting force for humiliation and embarrassment for adults, not of a parenting role model for parents to experience entertainment. Another young brash and sometimes uppity child character was found in the remake of True Grit (2010) though many found the movie among the best of the year and Winter Bones (2010) both young female leads.The best movies that seem to have children who are able to survive and prosper because they need to are reflected in such movies as The Secret Garden (1993), the animated Coraline (2009), or when children get to just explore and interact among themselves in both a childlike or adult way as in Stand By Me (1986), Holes (2003), or The Chronicles of Naria: The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe (2005), and more recently Super 8 (2011). Perhaps among the closest child-relational parallel movie to Real Steel may be the sci-fi children drama A Wrinkle In Time (2002) that has an nice balance of creativity, child-adult thinking mix and humor and drama and some of the best of young adult movies Whale Rider (2002) or The Lovely Bones (2009), The Tree of Life (2011), even the animated Incredibles (2004) or Spirited Away (2001).Another underdeveloped theme of this movie was the wasted potential the robotic-human interface dynamic which could have been used to an incredible affect with an almost A.I.: Artificial Intelligence (2001) mystic that was overlooked. Even today, the animated standard of motion capture has already established that the technology exists even today to replicate what is being presented as come futurist sports game (which if the audience interest and investors were willing could become reality today). To its credit, Real Steel avoids the overly dramatic stereotypical divorced wife hysteria though more could have been developed to even make these scenes more potent. Too little was shown in the way of Atom's rise through the ranks and then the sudden the title fight ultimatum and its resolution seemed overly simple and the antagonist too unnecessarily two-dimensional.The net result is another interesting but not particularly innovative nor creative movie that uses by the numbers' plot points and a boy character and using a robotic theme that could have generated a new level of experience.

title: Real Steel -aka- The Hollywood Machine
text: I like robots. I like robots that fight. So if I had gotten my full dose of fighting robots I might've been nicer to this movie. But I didn't get what I wanted. What I got was a trifle of a film that pretends to give connection from a kid that I was sick of in the first 5 minutes. I really did NOT like that whining, overacting slimy kid. The fact that I had to sit through painfully cheesy scenes with that little ham actor and Hugh Jackman made the whole thing barely watchable. By the way Hugh, what the hell kinda accent was that? So, chessy acting, predictable story, hack writing, good (not remarkable) special effects and yet this drivel went on to make $256 million, not including licensing, which I assume will be gigantic when Real Steel 2 comes out!?!? I'm not upset, just disappointed.

title: Super Movie
text: We saw an advanced screening on Sept 22. I thought it was going to be another one of those cheesy, campy, not really believable, warm fuzzy, type of underdog/rags to riches movies. I was actually surprised. It had some great plot twists, it had a real storyline. And while yes, there is some language sprinkled throughout, it did make a good family movie for older kids, 10+ (my opinion). The ending wasn't quite what I was expecting, but looking back I think I liked it better for that. Who wants an ending they can see coming to the entire movie?It had some great comedy moments. The relationships between the actors felt genuine and not overdone or forced. The robot animatronics was good. The robots themselves were fun and imaginative and definitely made me wish we really had this sport. I would so be there!

title: Cliched but uplifting underdog story
text: This is very much a classic tale of an underdog success story from rags to riches. Very few prominent robot films in mainstream Hollywood.The action sequences with the effects of the robots are very well done. The overall look and designs of the robots are well designed and it shows the creativity of these artists.The father son relationship is something which many people love seeing and although it is predictable, it's more about the journey along the way seeing the eventual growth of these characters.The story did grow once the son found the deserted robot "Atom" and it becomes more about him and the robot. Of course from there, we get the sense of where's it going, but it is wholesome in the sense of fatter and son bonding.Several highlights including one of the robot boxing matches with Atom and the red robot with two heads. Very thrilling and great choreographed. The finale robot battle with the great Zeus was also great all be it predictable.Considering this was a family targeted film, a happy ending here was definitely needed in a feel good way.

title: Cute movie
text: Kids only? What? I enjoyed this. Thankfully, they did not go into the direction I expected them to, which would have been robots hurting people.The wolverine does a decent job here, as do the other actors. Kind of hard to unsee Hugh Jackman as being the wolverine, but by the end of the movie, you do realize he's a different guy here.Simple movie, but if you're a kid or think like one - go for it.

title: Makes your feel good and is super entertaining!
text: Let's be clear... it's cheesy and has some mediocre cgi but it's good and it's fun. Hugh Is awesome too! A great watch and worth the money. I'd love a remake or a sequel! *wink* *wink*

title: Gr8 movie ,awesome vfx
text: I really like this movie becoz of the action as it drives u in and as it was co produced by steven spielberg ,i cant wait for part 2.

title: Boxing Movies touches heart, boxing robots too...
text: I hated boxing. When I first heard about LOTR, I thought it was a boxing movie. And I go not watching that movie for year, unless I came to know original plot from a friend. pathetic but true!!!But luckily I watched Cinderella man, and then that movie got me into boxing movies. Then I watched The Fighter. Those movies touch my heart. When I heard about Real Steel where Robots fight Boxing. I had no high hopes about it, but felt interested because the movie got The Wolverine. Now, I liked it and I like it much, seeing how realistic a science fiction movie can be. Seeing how a unknown son can change a father, how a son can rebuild a father's heart, I love the movie. FYI, this is the movie which will freshen your mind better than lots of comedy. No hard scene, but you may attempt to cry watching happy moments.A movie to watch with family. I rated it 8, and hope you will find my review helping.

title: Rocky Meets Rock'em Sock'em Robots....
text: The Good= To start off I absolutely loved the soundtrack I think they fit so well with the film, in fact I think each song helps us the audience with the scene, which including the Montage.
